DataElement.preferredName: Lung Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Pathologic Regional Lymph Node N Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of the regional lymph node involvement for the lung carcinoma based on evidence obtained from pathologic examination through completion of definitive surgery.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Information related to pathologic N stage for a lung tumor.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has but two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border. SYN pulmo.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pathologic; caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.:One criteria of the TMN staging system. N refers to the extent of lymph node involvement.

Concepts.definition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. N refers to the extent of lymph node involvement.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 9/13/17 tt transferred context; changed def - 1st letter upper case; changed Reg Status to Qualified. Updated to use Proprty based on NCIt concepts

ValueDomain.preferredName: Lung Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer Edition 7 N Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A finding about one or more characteristics of lung cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system.  This classification is used for both non-small cell and small cell lung carcinomas and for carcinoid tumors of the lung.  Sarcomas and other rare tumors of the lung are not included. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)_A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._One criteria of the TNM staging system. N refers to the extent of lymph node involvement._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lung cancer with metastasis to contralateral mediastinal, contralateral hilar, ipsilateral or contralateral scalene, or supraclavicular lymph nodes. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

Concepts.longName: Lung Cancer pN3 TNM Finding v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Lung cancer with metastasis to contralateral mediastinal, contralateral hilar, ipsilateral or contralateral scalene, or supraclavicular lymph nodes. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lung cancer with metastasis to ipsilateral mediastinal and/or subcarinal lymph nodes. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

Concepts.longName: Lung Cancer pN2 TNM Finding v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Lung cancer with metastasis to ipsilateral mediastinal and/or subcarinal lymph nodes. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Lung Cancer N1 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Lung Cancer N1 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lung cancer with metastasis in ipsilateral peribronchial and/or ipsilateral hilar lymph nodes and intrapulmonary lymph nodes, including involvement by direct extension. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Lung Cancer pN1 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Lung cancer with metastasis in ipsilateral peribronchial and/or ipsilateral hilar lymph nodes and intrapulmonary lymph nodes, including involvement by direct extension. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lung cancer with no evidence of metastasis to regional lymph nodes. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

Concepts.longName: Lung Cancer pN0 TNM Finding v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Lung cancer with no evidence of metastasis to regional lymph nodes. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lung cancer in which regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

Concepts.longName: Lung Cancer pNX TNM Finding v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Lung cancer in which regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

This classification is used for both non-small cell and small cell lung carcinomas and for carcinoid tumors of the lung.  Sarcomas and other rare tumors of the lung are not included. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)
A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.
